name: Coffee & Code
description:
Stop by for some Sunday morning coffee and coding!

This is a general topic/networking event, nothing language-specific. Just bring yourself, something to code on, and enjoy some coffee with (new) friends!

There's only room for about 10 or so people in the Community Room at this location, but there's more seating in the general cafe area as well. The Community Room has a large screen with a HDMI hookup and an array of outlets for plugging in, so it can be used for presenting/teaching/etc.

name: Intro to React Workshop
description:
An introductory workshop to using the React JavaScript library for building user interfaces.

---

Firstly, what this workshop is NOT:
- JavaScript tutorial (you should already have a good understanding of JS, ES6 syntax, etc.)
- Node/Build toolchain tutorial (you should already know how to serve up content to a browser, start up a http-server, etc.)
- External React library tutorial (We will not be covering topics like Redux, React Router, etc.)

---

In this workshop we'll explore the following:
- What is React, and what is it used for?
- Elements, Components, and how to compose and render them
- Props (passing data around)
- State (somewhat-persistent data within the client side application layer)
- Event handling
- JSX

We'll be learning by "doing", which means each portion of the workshop will require the attendees to code along and/or work on exercises.

The first portion will be "bare-bones" React to understand how it works, with the second half being more abstracted and in line with how the rest of the community typically works with the library.

The goal is that by the end of the workshop you will have built a simple React application that touches on all of the subjects listed above.

---

What to bring:
- Laptop

Setup before arriving:
- Optional: "npm install -g http-server"
- Optional: Sign up for a free codesandbox.io account through GitHub

name: React Components Workshop (Intermediate)
description:
A workshop centered around creating and reusing React components.

---

*** IMPORTANT ***
Firstly, what this workshop is NOT:
- JavaScript tutorial (you should already have a good understanding of JS, ES6 syntax, etc.)
- Introduction to React (you should understand the basics - or at minimum have already attended the Intro to React workshop)

---

In this workshop we'll explore the following:
- Component types and composition
- Props
- State
- Component lifecycle
- Render props (time permitting)

We'll be learning by doing, so we'll be coding along together as we explore each of the topics.

The goal is that by the end of the workshop you will have a better understanding of how components are created and reused throughout a React application.

---

What to bring:
- Laptop

Setup before arriving:
- Optional: Sign up for a free codesandbox.io account through GitHub

Some helpful links to study beforehand:
JavaScript classes - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes

description:
Women in Coding is hosting an Intro to HTML & CSS class at The Fayetteville Library. Sign up by going to the library's registration page here: https://www.fflib.org/women-coding-workshop

About:
Join the Syracuse Women in Coding group for an Intro to HTML and CSS: the building blocks of the web. Learn the fundamentals of using these two languages and build an online coffee shop menu with the instructor's guidance. The class is for adults and teens (11 years and up). Bring your own laptop, a limited number will be available.

Teacher:
This class will be taught by Women in Coding's cofounder, Zoe Koulouris. Zoe is a partner and software developer at Upstate Interactive. She specializes in HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Angular, NativeScript, Node.

Sponsor:
Big thank you to Hack Upstate for sponsoring our meetups. You can learn more about them at http://hackupstate.com/.

name: Intro to JavaScript - Library Workshop by Women in Coding
description:
This is a free introductory class on Javascript, the world's most popular programming language for a reason -- it's the primary way to build interaction on the web. Learning JavaScript is a logical next step once you've learned HTML/CSS. Our classes are open to everyone, so please share and bring a friend!
***Please register at https://www.fflib.org/women-coding-workshop-javascript

This course is especially designed for beginners new to programming concepts, like variables, data types and functions. It will also introduce the Document Object Model (DOM) and how to use it to change html pages. Students will exit this class with a good grasp of basic programming principles and the knowledge of how to manipulate HTML elements.

PREREQUISITES
It would be best to have a working knowledge of HTML for this class. There are many online resources to learn HTML, including this free course from Code Academy: https://www.codecademy.com/learn/web

name: Women in Coding - Intro to Mobile Development with JavaScript
description:
This is a free, introductory class on developing cross-platform mobile apps with JavaScript (the language of the web). With increasingly mobile users, it has never been more important to design applications for all devices. It has also never been easier for web developers to create native mobile applications using web technologies.

Zoe will start with a brief overview/history of cross-platform mobile development. Then, Zoe will give an overview of NativeScript, her framework of choice for native mobile development. Finally, we'll close by building our very own app! More info at: https://www.fflib.org/women-coding-workshop-javascript-part-2

‚Ä¢ What to bring
Bring your computer. All are welcome, but it's preferred to have working knowledge of web technologies (HTML, CSS, JavaScript).

name: Coffee & Code
description:
Stop by for some Sunday afternoon coffee and coding!

This is a general topic/networking event, nothing language-specific. Just bring yourself, something to code on, and enjoy some coffee with (new) friends!

There's only room for about 10 or so people in the Community Room at this location, but there's more seating in the general cafe area as well. The Community Room has a large screen with a HDMI hookup and an array of outlets for plugging in, so it can be used for presenting/teaching/etc.

name: Intro to Python and Arduino Lab by Women in Coding
description:
This month's Women in Coding event will be a two-part class at DeWitt Library. Please register for each part you plan to attend on the Library's website:
Intro to Python:
http://onlibdewitt.evanced.info/signup/EventDetails?EventId=2679&backTo=Calendar&startDate=2019/03/01
Arduino Lab:
http://onlibdewitt.evanced.info/signup/EventDetails?EventId=2680&backTo=Calendar&startDate=2019/03/01

Intro to Python 10 - 11:30am
Taught by Alison McCauley
Python is used for controlling and increasing the functionality of software, websites, databases, and can perform complex math with large data sets, among many other useful activities. With this readable, flexible programming language you can get the most out of your computer, for home or work applications.

Arduino Lab 12 - 1:30pm
Taught by Josh Wright
Arduino is an easy-to-use electronics controller that works with inputs and outputs to perform tasks assigned by the user. The Arduino software is great for beginners and flexible enough for advanced users.
In this exciting, hands-on workshop participants will use the Library‚Äôs Arduino kits to learn more about how Arduino works and the possibilities of what Arduino can do.

description:
Join us for our Code for Syracuse kickoff event. Code for Syracuse is a group of technologists with a simple purpose, work together on things that matter. We are partnering with local non-profits and local government build a better Syracuse for everyone. That means we need everyone: community leaders and coders, subject-matter experts and project managers, activists and designers, public servants and curious residents.

- Wrap up at 7:30 PM

Much thanks to our amazing sponsor Hack Upstate. Check out what they are up to at https://hackupstate.com Also, special thanks to Syracuse CoWorks for letting us use their awesome space. Check them out at http://www.syracusecoworks.com.

name: Coffee & Code
description:
Stop by for some Sunday morning coffee and coding!

This is a general topic/networking event, nothing language-specific. Just bring yourself, something to code on, and enjoy some coffee with (new) friends!

Also, it's October, so if you're participating in Hacktoberfest, stop down and share with us what you're doing or if you need any help!

There's only room for about 10 or so people in the Community Room at this location, but there's more seating in the general cafe area as well. The Community Room has a large screen with a HDMI hookup and an array of outlets for plugging in, so it can be used for presenting/teaching/etc.

name: Technology Learning Day Conference by Major League Hacking
description:
MLH's technology learning day conference is a global conference that allows the community to pick up new skills by experiencing a professional day of learning first-hand. Over the course of the day attendees will participate in a series of workshops where they‚Äôll learn skills such as publishing their first website using AWS, sending their first SMS with Twilio, Blockchain, building their first game in Unity and more. This conference is for high schoolers, college students, coding newcomers, and technology professionals who want to know more about the world of technology from industry experts.

MLH's Local Hack Day is a series of simultaneous global events designed to spark a passion for technology in your local community. Spend the day getting hands-on experience and collaborating in a welcoming environment. Whether you are learning to code or are an expert hacker, Local Hack Day is perfect for you and your community. Learn new skills, build new projects, and share your creations.

Talk schedule is currently TBD but we'll promise talks on web development, blockchain, game development, and more! The conference talks will start at 9AM and will continue to 7PM but you may come and go as you wish!

This event is being held at one of Syracuse's newest premier co-working spaces... ShareCuse. Your attendance gives you first peek at what it would be like to be a part of the downtown Syracuse co-working scene for your business, personal projects, and freelancing needs.

name: Code for Syracuse Monthly Hack Night
description:
Join us for our monthly night of Civic Hacking where we are currently working together on web-based projects related to housing issues in the Syracuse area.

Code for Syracuse is a group of technologists with a simple purpose, work together on things that matter. We are partnering with local non-profits and local government build a better Syracuse for everyone. That means we need everyone: community leaders and coders, subject-matter experts and project managers, activists and designers, public servants and curious residents.

*You should bring your laptop*

First Meeting Agenda:
- Event starts at 6:00 PM
- Food and informal introductions
- Introduction to Tableau Public by Amanda Darcangelo of Salt City Analytics, Project Lead of data visualization Group

- Update on housing projects
- Break into teams and hack on housing web projects.
- Wrap up at 7:30 PM

Much thanks to our amazing sponsor Hack Upstate. Check out what they are up to at https://hackupstate.com Also, special thanks to Syracuse CoWorks for letting us use their awesome space. Check them out at http://www.syracusecoworks.com.

To find out more information on our current projects, join our Slack Channel at: https://slackacuse.herokuapp.com/ where we are currently collaborating in the #code_for_syracuse thread.

name: Syracuse JavaScript Meetup | Topic: Hacktoberfest
description:
We are a group dedicated to discussing and working with the JavaScript programming language.

Currently we meet the third Tuesday of each month (this month its the fifth Tuesday - October 29), and each event has both a learning and interactive portion. Whether you‚Äôre an experienced JavaScript programmer or just getting started, we welcome and encourage all proficiency levels.

Each month we'll be exploring the "Current Topic" referenced in the Meetup title. If you're not familiar with the topic, come learn something new! Already a pro? Awesome! We can use some mentors to help out with questions. Check us out for some great discussions, food, and drink!

‚Ä¢ What to bring
Laptop

‚Ä¢ Important to know
Harassment-free meetup, regardless of topic

Women in Coding will be hosting workshop style classes once a month every second Saturday of the month, from 10am-12pm at The Tech Garden! Rather than having an instructor teach a specific topic, these workshops will give you the chance to work on a project or work through an online curriculum at your own pace. Never coded before? No problem. We'll help get you started. Each workshop will have at least one mentor there to provide support and answer questions.

‚Ä¢ What to bring
Bring your computer, questions and/or a project

‚Ä¢ Important to know
This month's mentors and their skills are TBD. Check for updates.

Big thank you to Hack Upstate for sponsoring our meetups. You can learn more about them at http://hackupstate.com/.

name: OpenHack: Code together, on anything.
description:
‚Ä¢ What we'll do
OpenHack is a casual social coding meetup with a simple purpose: Code together, on anything.

We welcome local developers and designers of all skill levels, interests, ages genders, you-name-it to get together to write code or push pixels. We‚Äôll provide good food, good people, and creative energy.

Here‚Äôs how OpenHack works:

* You can hack on anything! Any language, framework, public/open-source, personal projects, client work‚Ä¶ anything!
* You don‚Äôt have to have an idea to hack on, you can come join someone else
* We‚Äôll kick things off with a quick round of introductions, to say who you are, what you‚Äôre working on, and if you‚Äôd like help with your idea
* Food and drinks will be provided
* Feel free to join us - bring a laptop, a project, and a friend!

See more at http://openhacksyr.com

‚Ä¢ What to bring
A laptop if you're bringing a project, but not required

‚Ä¢ Important to know
Please review our Code of Conduct before attending: http://openhacksyr.com/code_of_conduct/

name: Syracuse JavaScript Meetup | Topic: TBD
description:
We are a group dedicated to discussing and working with the JavaScript programming language.

Currently we meet the third Tuesday of each month, and each event has both a learning and interactive portion. Whether you‚Äôre an experienced JavaScript programmer or just getting started, we welcome and encourage all proficiency levels.

Each month we'll be exploring the "Current Topic" referenced in the Meetup title. If you're not familiar with the topic, come learn something new! Already a pro? Awesome! We can use some mentors to help out with questions. Check us out for some great discussions, food, and drink!

‚Ä¢ What to bring
Laptop

‚Ä¢ Important to know
Harassment-free meetup, regardless of topic
